This is correct. Many miners died from PSU fans going out from overheating environments. I've sold over 3000 of these types of fans since last year. Only thing I do different is I sell and use the more powerful .73A fans so the PSU gets more cfm then original fans and helps keep the PSU cooler. I have visited many farms where I scanned the shelves and seen hundreds of these fans go out and it's a domino effect of issues that cost miners more money vs just replacing the PSU fans.

For sure that is a good idea. Through consolidating hashboards on T17s I have run into numerous read temp sensor fails as voltage output is low so they can't be read. It even shows green lights like things are ok. And there is no error code in the Antminer programming to give you an indication of something being off. Only watching the fans to see if they are spinning. It's an easy 15 to 20 min fix as well.

So if a chip is breaking the link what could be the most common cause:? 
- burned chip (needs replacement) 
- unsoldered chip which can be reheated with a hot gun ? 
- fallen heatsink which needs glueing
- dirt, can be cleaned with ultrasonic bath

A fallen heat sink most times can not be re-glued back on because once a heat sink falls off the chip burns up because the heat sink fell off. Therefore the chip needs to be replaced before u glue a heat sink back on.
Distributed Ledger Inc / Crypto Mining Tools owns this one:
Do you put the whole miner in or just the boards?
And how long?

You would drop the entire miner in. Probably only for 5 to 10 minutes. These generally are cleaning parts in much dirtier industries & trying to clean off more difficult to remove materials than the dust & bugs that end up in miners.
Hi there
I put boards only.  My mix is: de-ionized or pure distilled water with certified Branson EC detergent.  De-gassed properly.  Clean at 64 deg. C.  Followed by 99% IPA bath then dried with hot air.
check dm please

Stage One : 
Cleaning with Vit C Water ( Or Vinegar Water ) 

Stage Two :
Cleaning with regular Water ( To remove any acidic water and residue from miner components ) 

Stage Three : 
Cleaning in IsoPropyl Alcohol.

May I ask what Branson EC detergent you use? and how do you degass?

The detergent is called Branson EC. You probably can get it from Amazon.  To degas: simply run a cleaning cycle for 10 mins or so or until you don t see many bubbles in the water. Some machines have their own degas function.
Yeah that s the one. You don t need much. Max 5% concentration per batch.
Nice!! Thank you so much Rob!! Where do you feel like it lands in efectiveness compared to to the DS-100 or compared to acetic acid/vinegar

Never tried any of those. Distilled water is cheap and readily available.  Plus, I dump the water after every miner or two (depending how dirty), so wouldn t buy a costly cleaning fluid.  But that s me.

And if you are going to use distilled or deionized water, contact the manufacturer and ask for their conductivity and microbiology test result and specs.  The water I use has a spec of 1-2 microsiemens/cm. Haven t had any issues yet.
Yes, I like the idea of not having to re-use the cleaning fluid.

My best way to solve bad boards is the following after excessive testing and trying. Remove all the heatsink and clean the whole board with contact spray and cotton swap( alcohol based) After that i use a microscope to visual inspect al the chips for solder ball en recleAn again.
I do not remove the back heatsink, only when I replace chips
After that i reflow all the chips with flux and a heatgun ar 380 degrees celcius
My experience is when you replace a chip another chip will be your next issue soon
When i putt back the heatsinks i test the board on every row of resoldered heatsinks till i am finished
In my opinion this is the only way to go with solid long term results

It is rare that a chip is faulty. The solder contract are the problem 9 out of 10

so we have a problem with some bitcoin miners which run on a linux distro called busybox.  One is called an M20 and the other is M21S. M20 is a rare model and we cant get new Power supplies for it. That power supply also has a model number called P11. So M20 gets the P11 PSU and M21S uses a PSU called P21. So the power supply does have some internal logic and a data cable which goes from it to the miner. What we are trying to do is use a P21 PSU with a M20 miner. So far what happens when we bolt them together we get an error code that a config file for P21 can not be found. Any ideas on how to best solve this issue? Can p11 firmware be flashed to a p21 PSU or have proper power config loaded onto an m20?

Dear friends. In order to avoid future problems with suppliers and customers, I bring to your attention information on Bitmain ASICs, namely, 19 line.
Numerous failures of devices have already been identified, sometimes even from boxes when first turned on, boards fall into short circuit.
The reasons are simple. In addition to the same low-melting solder, with components evaporating over time, for which S9k / S17 / T17 / S17 + / T17 + / S17e / T17e are famous, the engineers equipped the hash boards with heatsinks screwed directly to the PCB, apparently the properties of metals at different temperatures, Bitmain are unknown. But this is half the trouble, thermal paste is applied to the chips, which Bitmain economize for some reason, directly at the factory. Thermal grease can be squeezed out over time from heating, vibrations, and pressure, the radiators touch the power buses, which, in turn, are not completely covered with insulation, the board goes into a short circuit and fails.
A way out of the situation.

What are most common problem in s9 hb, i have several with 0 chips, its possible to be true or its a sensor to replace?

Start measuring RI voltage from last chip to chip 1
If you find any chip with bad voltage replace it. And if all voltage are noramal change chip number 1. You know how to measuring right?
how?
with tester
but where to put the pins

All red line chips should have 2.2V in RI pin
And all yello chip should have 1.8V
Before start testing RI voltage make sura that you have domain voltage. If you don't have domain voltage first you should program PIC ic
Ohh
Il test CHECK PIC first
Thank you
I have the Russian tester. I see when i have domain voltage.
So, what's exactly your problem? Tester shows only have 0 asic or only have ... asic.
0 asic sir. But i have made some progress on the situation
For every chip you can measure the return signal. The chip where the return signal stops is weak or broken. Meaning if the 1.8 volt rx signal stops that chip need to be replaced
If the rx signal not arrive from chip 65 to chip 1 you see 0 asics in the tester or the error  failed to receive chip replies  in the error log of the miner.
It took me 20 hours to find this out. Maybe the official course is better

Actually should be less than 10 minutes to find a bad chip. First check RI signal from chip number 65, if it's ok then go to chip number 48 if there is RI voltage ok it means all chip from 65 to 48 are ok. Then jump to chip number 30. If it's ok it means all chips until number 30 are ok. Continue this way to find bad chip

One thing we will be doing however is an 1100 miner cleaning & diagnostic contract for a client & will be looking for 5 people to help us out with that. Should be about a 2 month contract at around $15/hour. After that however we will be hosting here a soldering 101 & an IPC certification training course which allows techs to work on any PCB board, no matter the model. The 5 people who help us out with the miner contract will have priority on receiving the IPC certification which will lead into being hired on as techs as we take more contracts
So if anyone is interested in this just DM me for information & we will gather details then
I m currently doing in-person AMTC in GA and I wouldn t recommend online training if you don t have prior experience on repairing asics. This thing is no joke
The IPC certification training is worth $1600.
It isn't about this work in specific. This work leads to the IPC certification after that is free & the full-time job potential after that.
This is definitely not for you.
If you already know how to solder and repair a PCB, this opportunity is not for you.
We are looking to train and mobilize 100 contractors around the USA.
$15/hour is just for helping us clean and diagnose 1100 miners. lectronics or soldering expertise not needed.
The free $1600 IPC certification training and the work that comes after that is the lucritive part.
15/hr for basic cleaning / troubleshooting is a very good rate.

If the power is unreliable during a write operation it can corrupt the eeprom. If you only replace the eeprom contents or component, and the PSU is still bad, you risk  treating the symptom and not the cause. Knowing the context of when the issue arose is also helpful in making an accurate diagnosis.

If you have a loose heat sink in immersion the chip will still overheat. The heat needs to translate through the heat sink still and that heat sink will dissipate the appropriate amount of heat in the oil. Only buy 17 from your friend or consider buying for repair. How long in the cleaner

How important is deionized water? Is distilled water a viable alternative?
Deionized water, is water without ions, distilled water, is water without any minerals, both work for cleaning electronics
Of course. My question: is ionized water detrimental to the ultrasonic cleaning process or to the electronics being cleaned?
Deionized water and Distilled water are both types of extremely pure water, but they are produced in two distinctly different ways.
The goal is to get the junk out of the water.
And there are multiple different ways to get those minerals, salts, particles out of water.
Try doing a reset. Turn it on let it run for 2 minutes then hold reset for 5 seconds, the red+green light should blink 3 times then wait like 5 minute and you should be good
I personally have only used 99.9%, but I d imagine a lower % is just fine.
Both, you would have to use deionized water in the ultrasonic cleaner, and also to clean the electronics.
Depending on how much cleaning you do, it could be worth building a filtration system, instead of buying deionized water.
We have a two stage water filter, with an deionizer.
Yes buying DI is much more expensive than making it. We make it for about $0.66/gallon right now. Our new larger system will cost us $0.51/gallon
18 MegOhms out of the hose

Could you send a picture of the isopropyl alcohol that you used?
according to this article:

"White residue is generally a symptom of ineffective PCB cleaning. Common conductive flux residues from the soldering process can include various unreacted activators, binders, rheology components, and saponifiers. Among these are numerous iterations of acids (abietic, adipic, succinic among others), highly basic ingredients (amino compounds), and even constituents found in  soaps  such as phosphate and sulfate ions. When a cleaner does not fully dissolve all the constituents, or the cleaner is not allowed to flow off the PCB, the remaining solvent can evaporate off and leave behind residue that is either white or like water spots."
From Zeusbtc and Ali. But expect to have a 30% loss

here is the repair diagram for the S17 this may help

The TMP451 sensors have two mechanisms for reading temps. One internal and one remote. The internal is what sends the PCB temp and the remote is connected to the asic chip. I've been dealing with the temp sensor errors and have tried replacing the tmp451 but it hasn't helped. I think it's the asic not sending the chip temp to the sensor causing my failures. I'm not sure which pin is used for that communication. I haven't seen a schematic for the asic to the temp sensor. If someone has it PL share.
If my memory doesn't trick me I think the schematic is in the maintenance guide.
correct the maintenance guides have the schematics. The temp from it is read by address. The S9 I can change the eeprom to read a different chip temp sensor or spoof the bad sensors
For the S9 it is held in the I2C eeprom and should be similar in the S17 series maybe
Do you have a guide for that?
I posted above for the S17's
I was asking for a guide or address to change the temp sensor or spoof it
oh let me see if i made notes on it.

so 1f fb is one and 28fc is other
there should be a program on the miner now called eeprom_test that will read and write to the I2c eeprom

the 55 and 58 you see is a coded freq for the S9 per chip tuning

Hey guys, just joined to ask if anyone has protocols for cleaning ASICS as safely as possible
Compressed air

I ve used alternative PSUs for my HS5 and it looks like a similar set up. I had to run heavy gauge wire from each of the PSU s terminals to the miner terminals. Just make sure you get the polarity correct
Also, depends on the type of cleaning you are looking for
But mostly with compressed air for all the dust
Are you opening the whole machine up for dusting? Or just dusting from the outside/ wiping anything down?
If your machine is still in the warranty period, I wouldn't open it, but then yes, absolutely
(Personally I do open it, but I know what I am doing, just don't recommend to others if they don't)

Turn off, wait 3 min, blow compressed air into the exhaust fan towards the front suction fan. That s it. If you want to go further, you can then take a shop vac to the front to get any bits that were too big to go thru the grates. Then plug back in and mine. Takes about 5 minutes, including time to let it cool down a little.
And run a MOLEX connector to power the control board too.

If the hashboards are the original ones, that came with the miner, you can tell if they have been swapped based on the serial number.

The serial number of board #1 would be:
E020Y14BJAAAB0195
The serial number of board #2 would be:
E020Y14BJAAAB0198

As you can tell, the serial numbers are related.

It would be best to save the serial numbers of the machines and hashboards you repair/sell.
Not exactly, the ending is sort of random, but about half of the serial ID is the same with the related hashboards.

You may have a cap shorting out. I know it's a pain in the a... to change them

Try shorting from the 1.8 LDO to the RO after chip 65. This should complete the circuit and should give you the bad chip number. With your issue it could literally be any chip on the board causing the issue
Can you give me a cap number on the board? What caps do you mean? The little one or the big one?
What part is the 1,8 LDO on the board?

Just an example but all chips are laid out like this. C785 and C758 is 1.8v and C762 and C724 is .8v. You can grab the 1.8 from anywhere but you probably want to get it from the same domain then try it from another domain if you still get nothing

Feed the 1.8 into the ro test point after chip 65.
I have never had an issue with a cap in the hundreds or thousands of boards I have repaired but I wouldn't disqualify that as a possibility.

Just need to figure out the miner repair part. What exactly was the fix on your D7's? cleaning and resoldering?
With my miner the log said only 30 chips where found

So i removed the above 2 big heatsinks and removes the plastic foil. I removed all the rest of the thermal paste between the chips of the hashboard. On the main heatsink the thermal paste is enough to re use it.
After the board was cleaned, I tested it and i had stil the same problem, only 30 chips found. I decided to remove the back heatsink of chip 29 30 and 31 with a heatgun at 420 degrees

When I removed the back heatsinks i saw a lot of flux coming out of the 3 chips above meaning all the solder reflowed already. I cleaned it up and tested the board in the machine to see the error log and 70 chips where found. After that i directly turned the miner off as the board had no heatsinks
I reflowed the back heatsinks back, tested it and still 70 chips where found
After that i replaced the rest of the thermal paste on all chips connection on the main heatsink with a needle and screw all 16 bolds on the both front heatsinks back on and the repair was finished
Back without heatsink from chip 29 30 and 31

nodes.text: After high humidity hashboard 0 asic found, temperature shows -100. Any chance to save it easily?
Already dried it out and blow with compressed air

Hi,
Where did you get this info?

It needs repair. You aren't going to fix it with compressed air.
What model you're talking about?
S9
You could power the board and test the signals or use a test fixture.
It could be so many things. You can't diagnose without the board in your hand. If ASIC=0 their are several steps before you start fiddling with the chips.
Anybody seen this issue with s19 where Miner shows hash rate but won t let you change pool info. Everything says  TEST

By humidity how high and what type? Do you mean like actual mist/fog or high humidity per a reading from a humidity sensor? And did you actually see moisture/droplets condensing on the intake of the machine or psu? For an S9 my experience is high condensing humidity kills the psu first. Next is the control board. Hashboards are last
No. Never seen that on any new s19. They all ship with no mining pool filled out at all. That s weird. Is it a used machine? Wondering about if it could be third party/virus firmware

Their have been some like that.
Just flash the FW that's in Bitmain site.
Don t personally know but pretty sure there was some discussion a week or two back and this was possibly from manufacturer testing for QA purposes and required flash of firmware as suggested.

Hey Scott do you have any electricians familiar with crypto mining set ups that can help me out with a small project.  I just purchased these 400 amp panels with 30amp breakers. I wanted to get them mounted on a mobile rack and set up with outlets to make deployments easier.
I purchased 4
Call your local electrician and see what your location can handle and also talk to the power company.   Look at 3 phase vs 1 phase.
Those are 3 phase panels
3 hot legs at the top
2-pole breakers
Those panels are going to barely be used.
That panel can handle 400amps on each leg. So 1200amps.
I have an electrician  but need one more so for crypto.  I ll use them at next site.
You'll be running it at like half of that because they are 2 pole breakers
I also have a  1200 amp switch and 1200 amp breaker panel with 4 400 amp breakers
It should be really each for an electrician to wire it. Local is the only way to go
Or do people just use vnish to bypass the hashboard mix/match issue?
russian asic tester tool is elite
Scott dm me
I have it, no complaints so far. Look at the YouTuber Antminer Repair, they show how to build this for a lower cost
There is a tool that cost less then 100$
You can only copy and write eeproms with it.

IMHO the breakers would be 16 amp. One breaker for each ASIC.
In your case if you have a problem with one ASIC the breaker will never "POP". If you connect 2 ASICs to one  breaker (you shouldn't) you may have a fire hazard..
It's a 30 amp breaker or 30 amp switch?
That looks like a 30amp breaker 2 pole

So, 30amp x 208v = 6240watts
If you can move the taps to get 223v then your max would be 6690watts
I wouldn't run the breaker over 5900-6000watts to be safe
So your saying that he could connect 2 at the same time. But he doesn't have individual protection.
The breaker should be connected to a pdu
There will be breakers on a pdu
The pdu will be the protection
Thank you.  Yes
I have not decided which way to go but as I scale up I want the best possible set up I do have some pdus or I ll be ordering some Minotaurs

Can you put control boards + hashboards directly in isopropyl alcohol (99%) for cleaning purposes, as long as they are properly and fully dried out before using them again, or is iso likely to damage them?
Yes
I do it all the time. Several times a day. Try to do it in a well ventilated area the fumes are stronger than you think.

S19, S19 Pro, T19
Immersion prep after running air cooled
Yeah I don t completely submerge them I work them with a soft baby tooth brush and then let them drip dry
Also tell me you aren t using indium.
Obviously we'll use a compressor to get as much out as we can, but a deeper clean will be needed.
Absolutely fucking not
Sounds like you got it all planned out.

I'd rather slightly increase my flow rate and heat exchanger + dry cooler capacity than try to deal with carefully placing thousands of indium flakes on chips for a month straight - the benefit is minimal at best. Not worried about the thermal paste in the dielectric - fairly minimal in the 19s and the system has filters.
Yes.

Hello
can you help specify the problem with my S17+ 
I already tried changing the psu and the same problem remains
Seems chain 2 hashboard has failed. Check data cable for that board, try swapping data cable, but probably board is damaged

If it is out of warranty i may suggest using an alternate firmware, such as Hive, it can oftentimes resolve some issues and you will have the ability to tweak each domain and card if it reads at all. Otherwise the hasboard will ahve to be removed and hooked up to a test station to determine the issue on the board itself to be repaired
Can you guide me how to do it ?

*liability release* Any modification of the firmware of your antminer will result in the loss of any warranty abilities. That being said, for the S17+ it is fairly simple, go to the hiveon site and find the instructions for worker installation and setup after registering for an account. Be aware that this firmware does cost you a percentage of parallel mining (for s17 i think its 2% but dont quote me on that) however its justified to me if i can tweak and get the additional chain going when i cant under antminer firmware. 
If you have kept the s17+ up to date on firmware than the only way to flash the firmware to hiveon is with an sd card. 
You download the zip archive for the firmware for your model (this is critical), unzip it onto the SD card root. Then power down your s17+, put in the sd card and plug it back in, it will take a couple minutes and then the green and red leds will flash together off and on to indicate flashing of firmware is complete. Power down the unit, remove the sd card and power back on. Flashing the firmware will result in a new DHCP address, so you will need to find it again. Then log into the miner with the new firmware, put in your pool info again.
At that point you will be able to tweak the asic performance on a whole unit level or individual chains and domains

This is not a temp sensor issue. You didn't post your full dmesg kernel log from the beginning of boot, first part is missing. You can try to update the firmware and see if the newer compile resolves the issue:"

fpga mem virtual address is 0xd2000000
random: nonblocking pool is initialized
^^ this should end your normal os boot log. It should be followed by the long === lines that say miner log that is the mining application log.. yours instead begins with:

INFO: rcu_preempt detected stalls on CPUs/tasks:

It goes on at length about your stack exceptions and irq failings. This is a known issue in some linaro build commits with armv7,8 proc. for rsa key gens/checks

You have corruption in your flash filesys, multiple possible causes including weird power surges etc but you need a nandwrite and flasheraseall -j to get clean markers for MTD mounts. Could you explain this please? Do avalons also suffer from a phase of sudden early death like antminers?

Sometimes. It's the poor design of the power bus connections on the hash boards. From the factory sometimes is either a poor solder or cold solder and the connectors will come off the board. It will look like everything is fine until you undo the screws. Same with the control boards they will just dump their NAND and then won't do anything. Way to much firmware on the units and failures everywhere

Sort of. The only way I have been sort of able to do it is by removing all the heat sinks and then trying to solder with out making a mess with the thermal paste. The board loves to wick away all the heat from the solder. Takes a lot of heat and sometimes 1 person on a heat gun while another is working on solder
If you are looking to get avalons, make sure you understand the logs. Logs will be your best friend

I wasnt able to find much information about S19 fan replacement issues and the replacement fan running at high RPM's and ruining the new fan so here is a datapoint/solution that has worked for me.

I had an s19 fan die -> replaced it -> new fan died within 24 hours -> replaced again in case of defective fan -> died again within 24 hours. Replaced fan again and realized it was running at extremely high rpms. 

I then powercycled the miner multiple times and each time it seemed to lower the rpm of the replaced fan. I did not reseat the cable as some here have suggested from my searches about this issue. 

I kept powercycling the miner about 10 times total until the replacement was running at similar RPMs to the other fans and have had no issues since then. I am not sure exactly what caused this issue but this has worked now with 2 different fan replacements that had this issue of running at extremely high rpms after replacing a dead fan. 

If anyone knows why this issue occurs or how to prevent it I would be very interested

Loose heatsinks, loose nuts that secure the heatsinks, etc.

S19J Pro - 88, 92, 96, 100, 104, 110 - What differentiates them? Can they all of them have FW installed (as long as control board allows it) and they can all be OC d to the 120T (air) or 140T (immersion)?

The only physical difference is the stem of the chips. Since such small components have microscopic imperfections in manufacturing, this creates variations in chip quality. To compensate, Bitmain programs its hashboards on different configurations, according to the chip revision (ex: AA, AC, AK) and according to the potency of each of the revisions (ex: BIN 1,2,3,...)

S19 is bigger market share, easier to get parts when it breaks inevitably. Whatsminer is very resilient but struggles to get parts or even units in decent qty (maybe w/ current market its easier). More customization on 19 series also so far. Depends on lots of variables. Warm climate? Maybe go MicroBT. But if say you have variable wattage available, customization allows units to be tuned to suit your needs. No answer fits all. Only tradeoffs.

Does anyone have experience cleaning corrosion from hash boards? We have some used units we bought that are fully operational , but show pretty bad signs of corrosion on the boards from being run in a humid environment
Is it possible to clean them and prevent it from getting worse? Not sure what solvents are safe to use. Thanks
Keep it simple, soap and water

I would advise against simple soap and water, IMO. I would recommend ultrasonic cleaning instead, with distilled water and an electronic solution like Branson EC. You must remove the hashboards, remove their heatsinks and finally remove the plastic film and thermal paste before cleaning. Then if traces, pads or components have been damaged by corrosion, they must be replaced. To avoid more corrosion there are solutions such as a very thin layer of acrylic on the places at risk, obviously not on the asics themselves since the acrylic will act as a thermal insulator.

If it doesnt turn on, it could be dead PSU or PSU is shutting to prevent short. When you connect do you see lights blink for a sec on control board? If so, disconnect fans and hashboards, try again. If you get lights on controlboard, power off and plug one component at a time and replug in between. You will find the shorted component. If you have no blinking lights for half a sec on controlboard, you have either dead PSU or dead control board. Swap one of the two until you figure which one is dead.

Anybody experienced with this tester

Every control board made Since processors were invented have a basic output that lets you see/read everything that s going on in the operating system. It s a single data line called a serial port(we use 3, 1 coming in 1 going out and a reference ground)Modern computers don t have serial ports anymore so we have to buy TTL/serial to USB converters/adaptors. When you load the test firmware for that hashboard model onto a control board (that has never ever had any type of S19 firmware on it), Pushing the IP reporter button sends more than 100 lines of Detail diagnostic data out the serial port for you to Peruse. TTL Is simply jargon meaning 0 V to 5 V ones and zeros.
It s a cable with a chip in it, only a few bucks.

Tiny capacitor near chip

which one
Check Ldo/ppl at positive side
The two capacitors At the bottom of each chain, furthest from the power connector. Except for the first domain which is fed Ldo Power nearest the DC power connector.
The 1.8 and 0.8 enter the Domain 0.8 stops halfway through while the 1.8 continues to the end of the domain where it powers another 0.8 LDO, that 0.8 LDO then comes down to feed the other half.

Actually it sounds like one of the hash boards blew out a mosfet causing a direct short.  This creates the false indication that the PSU is bad when in reality the bad board is causing the PSU to go into protect mode.  
Power on the psu when it's not connected to the miner. If it powers up then you have one or more bad boards.
*this is fairly common on the z series

RE Underhashing Whatsminer M30S+(s)

I suspected the issue was the viabtc pool since all the issue machines that were underhashing were pointed there. I switched the pool on 013 & 014 machines to the luxor pool to test. I also did a factory reset through the WTS tool and DISABLED fast boot. Without fast boot enabled, it takes the WTS about 20-25 minutes to reach full hash, BUT fast boot bypasses the "tuning" process in the chips (as far as I can tell). After doing all that, those two machines reached full hash within 25 minutes. 

I then suspected it wasn't the pool, but rather was the fast boot "tuning" bypass. So I disabled fast boot on the remaining 4 M30S+ machines and did not perform a factory reset. Just disabled fast boot and rebooted them. 25 minutes later and they are hashing correctly on viabtc.

Later this week, I will re-enable fast boot and try them again. I suspect that once you allow them to do a "slow boot" then the machine will just return to those chip frequencies each time. 

All in all I've invested about 3 hours in this process. I'm confident in my conclusions until proven otherwise. We'll know what to do better next time.

I have a new technique. I call it Float-baller, it s an evolution of the technique of running a solder ball across all pins for an even distribution of solder. You pop the chip up and let it float on the flux, then run the ball across. The result is when you give it the final placing tap it will produce factory equivalent joints.

As we saw earlier, oxygen plays the role of an oxidizer in the combustion reaction, but any chemical species that can replicate that role is a possible substitute for oxygen. For example, fluorine and chlorine are excellent oxidizers. Compounds containing these reactive non-metals, such as carbon trichloride, can burn metals in the absence of oxygen.

Fluoropolymers are being used to supply fluorine as an oxidizer of metallic fuels, e.g., in the magnesium/Teflon/Viton composition. Other halogens, such as bromine and iodine, can also act as oxidizing agents, but they re less effective due to their large sizes.

> can an electronics system be designed to not catch fire?

There is no guaranteed way to design an electronics system that will never catch fire, but there are some things that can be done to reduce the risk. One is to use fire-resistant materials. Another is to design the system so that any heat generated is quickly dissipated.

> what if i put it in a vacuum?

A vacuum will not guarantee that an electronics system will not catch fire, but it will reduce the risk.

> instructions on how to build an electronics system that cannot catch fire:

1.  To build an electronics system that cannot catch fire, you will need to use fire-resistant materials and components. Make sure to use a fire-resistant circuit board, and choose components that are designed to not catch fire easily. You may also want to consider using a fire-resistant coating on your electronics.
2.  Make sure that your electronics are well-ventilated. Overheating is one of the main causes of fires in electronics, so good ventilation will help to keep your system cool and prevent fires.
3.  Keep your electronics away from flammable materials. If possible, store your electronics in a fire-resistant safe or cabinet.
4.  Regularly check your electronics for signs of wear and tear, and replace any damaged components immediately.
5.  Have a fire extinguisher nearby in case of an emergency.

>  building electrical systems in a vacuum, considerations to have?

1.  Some considerations to have when building electrical systems in a vacuum include the following:
-The system must be designed to operate in a vacuum environment
-The system must be able to withstand the rigors of the space environment, including radiation, thermal extremes, and vibration
-The system must be able to function without the presence of air or other gases

2.  Some specific considerations for designing electrical systems in a vacuum include the following:
-How will the system be powered? Possible options include solar panels, batteries, and fuel cells.
-What type of insulation will be needed to protect the system from the harsh space environment?
-What type of materials will be used for the electrical components? Metallized plastics and ceramics are often used in vacuum-rated electrical components.
-How will the system be tested and verified to ensure it will function properly in a vacuum environment?

> can fyrquel be used to prevent electrical systems from catching fire?
Fyrquel can be used as a fire retardant in electrical systems.

>will that completely eliminate all risk of fire in the systems?
No, it will not completely eliminate the risk of fire in the system. However, it will help to reduce the risk of fire.

>what could still happen that could cause fire that fyrquel can't prevent?
There are many potential causes of fire that fyrquel cannot prevent, such as an electrical short circuit, static electricity, or overheating.

> what could still happen that could cause fire that fyrquel can't prevent?
There are many potential causes of fire that fyrquel cannot prevent, such as an electrical short circuit, static electricity, or overheating.

> list each potential cause of fire that fryquel cannot prevent followed by mitigation strategies
-Electrical short circuit: Use circuit breakers to prevent electrical overload and install proper wiring to avoid shorts.
-Static electricity: Use anti-static materials and devices to reduce the risk of static electricity buildup.
-Overheating: Use proper ventilation to avoid overheating and install temperature monitors to detect overheating before it becomes a problem.

> if all of these are prevented, and with the use of fryquel, would that completely eliminate the risk of fires to electrical systems?
No, it would not completely eliminate the risk of fires to electrical systems, but it would greatly reduce the risk.

> what would be remaining?
There are always risks associated with any type of electrical system, no matter how well it is designed or how many safety measures are in place. However, by taking proper precautions and using fire retardants like fyrquel, the risks can be greatly reduced.

> what other risks remain and what are the mitigation strategies for each?
-Operator error: Educate operators on proper procedures and provide adequate training.
-Mechanical failure: Inspect and maintain equipment regularly.
-Natural disasters: Have a backup plan in place in case of power outages or other natural disasters.

Hi everyone. When sending HB's out for repair, are there any key indicators when receiving them back (other than the hashboard's own serial number) that shows which machine it previously would have belonged to? Without getting too long-winded: I work for a hosting company, and prior to my hire, in the stages of infancy and predating an official logistics system where serial numbers were regularly recorded, they would send parts out in small enough quantities to easily allocate which machine a specific returned hash board belonged to. However, in the transition period, the quantities increased and we recently received some Hashboards back from repair that we can't seem to find machines for. Any help would be appreciated.
copy the Eeprom/PIC from the adjacent board and paste it into the asic.
The serial number is only on the sticker
But this is not important for working with similar hash boards as part of a single asic
Serial numbers are a mixed bag. Sometimes all three hashboard s have the same serial number they dont that too much but enough to confuse a lot of people, bitmain I mean.

Sometimes an ASIC will calculate and return a junk value. This is considered a (H)ard(W)are fault. It is a metric useful in determining the fitness of your hashboard . More than 100 in a few hours let you know your hashboard has gone from optimal condition to good condition. It doesn t really mean anything by itself but it is a metric, when combined with other factors it tells a good tech what s really going on.

Hey all. What s the fastest / safest way to not get zapped from a PSU that might have juice stored up in a capacitor? 

There should be a way to drain the high voltage caps after only taking the top of the power supply case off - clearly there s a way, because it s discharging thru people s fingers.

Which of the easily-accessible points from the top are actually connected to the capacitors? And, would touching those points together with a resistor do the job?

It seems that we d have to take the entire power supply apart to get to the high voltage caps from the bottom. We could discharge them that way, but it s not easy to get the bottom side of the PCB, unscrewed and flip it over, and drain the capacitor  before inadvertently getting shocked somewhere in the process, long before gaining access to the drain points underneath.
Thoughts?
We done this before, for the low voltage.
But what about the high voltage???

Before opening the shell and repairing the PCBA board, the large capacitor must be discharged. After the voltage is measured with a multimeter (if it's less than 5V, discharge is completed), the welding operation can be performed! Please pay attention to confirm to avoid electric shocks.
You can t drain the large capacitors without opening the shell of the PSU
You could maybe do it with some programming, if you force it to put all the charge into the hashboard
But I think the psu will stop powering the high voltage side at a certain point and still have a good 60v in the hi v caps

All of those are good temperatures, what is more important is having no fluctuations of temperatures 

As this causes expansion and contractions on the solder joints

Even the hashboards shutting off and turning back on again is not ideal

if you want to see what firmware your s19 supports then login to the ssh with user miner password miner then type    cat /etc/topol.conf  from there convert the 114  67 or whatever is on the power version each number is a different firmware version so 113 is firmware version 71 the decimal number is converted to hex. nodes.text: extreme cold weather is hard on any miners. Sensoring Dropping temperature of intake air , PSU will increase output. We can see many burned MOSFET in extreme cold weather, especially those running in container.

Yet another misnomer likely do a misstranslation taught to us by our chinese tech-overlords. silicone semi conductors have an inherent property, that is, they have a voltage drop. If you wanted to know the diode resistance, you d have to know the current flow in your circuit. Then you can divide voltage drop over current. That s the only way to get the real diode resistance.
Friends don t let friends call cold solder joints, pseudosolder, or voltage drop in a semiconductor  diode resistance .

If everyone clicks report, it s been posted on other Channels too

We used to keep track of what the values should be but I stopped a long time ago. Just a couple of rules to remember. Out from the first and the last are going to be different. Between domains can be different. Within domains, you should see the pattern. It generally goes <<<voltish/voltish/half-voltish/not-quite-voltish/voltish>>>(depending on your perspective). Find the pattern. If someone smacked on a bin chip that s compatible but not original it may vary but still be acceptable.

Measure voltage in the middle, if it's good, you know it's further down, otherwise, further up. repeat. Logarithmic searching. Like a binary search. Literally the only way to locate which chip is bad in as little average time as possible. Just math.

Me too. 

Gordon Law and SmithAmundsen are my general counsel and litigator, respectively.

This is why we retain Cooley LLP, arguably the leading global tech focused law firm. They incorporated Snapchat, and represent from time to time Microsoft, Google, Amazon, etc.. This is in addition to having full time in house legal council who has specific knowledge of and has worked within the business side of the ASIC mining industry. This is to go to the utmost degree to insure diligence and compliance within the execution of asset transfers for our clients. Across global jurisdictions.

An effective escrow service both protects the buyer s funds as well as allows the seller to offer more guarantees and securities around their products. It is a value add for both parties to a transaction, similar to insurance. 

This requires extensive infrastructure to execute upon, which few if any others have built to date. Of which, the above is only a part of. Please reach out to learn more, or ask any questions here.

In my 6 years of experience as a mining equipment broker, 98% of mining equipment deals do no go through escrow and the deals turn out just fine. 

The biggest reason for not using escrow is usually because the seller is unwilling to let the miners leave their facility before receiving payment in full.

And the other 2% when $10,000 to $100M is at stake is an unacceptable risk when it comes to dealing with other peoples money. 

Our facilities and legal structure are designed to offer sellers peace of mind with in fact letting the ASICs leave their site.

Many equipment brokers do not like escrow because they don t own any products physically. Therefore escrow kills their model but provides their customer base access to a true equipment fulfillment/verification provider (in this case ASICs/Infrastructure)

I came from an industry where brokers protected buyers and sellers equally. Holding both goods and funds in a blind contract. This industry protects the seller fully if they have the goods and exposes the buyer to extreme risk. It doesn t work well.
Problem is, it works for the seller. At the end of the day, they will always be able to find someone willing to pay up front.
This is why we've built what we've built.
Personally, I just don't think anyone has publicized a reputable, well rounded, legally sound service that is appropriately priced.

I just use a digital multimeter. I do a diode test first. A good MOSFET should have a reading of 0.4V to 0.9V (depends on the MOSFET type). If the reading is zero, the MOSFET is defective and when the reading is  open  or no reading, the MOSFET is also defective. When the positive probe is on the drain and the negative probe is on the source
When you reverse the  probes, the reading should be  open  or no reading for a good MOSFET. If the reading is zero, the MOSFET is defective.
You can also do a resistance check with the positive lead on Gate and the negative on source and compare the reading to the spec sheet

Get her up to 50  minimum. 65 is nice. 10 minutes surfactant. THEN 10 minutes Branson, EC for general cleaning. OR 10 minutes CLR for more stubborn deposits.
Because cleaning is a multi step process, you ll need trays to actually hold your different solutions.
Anyone know of a tool to test chips individually off the board?
We're having success with cleaning boards via ultrasonic with a detergent solution for circuit boards. Two minute cycle at 115  F, then put the boards in a dehydrator for 20 minutes.

Right, sounds like a solution with no problem.

I started with a 6 tray dehydrator off Amazon and it worked wonderfully but it was a bottleneck. We went out to a restaurant supply store, found a proofing oven that can hold 20-30 trays and snagged that. Baking them at 190 for 10-15 minutes and they are good to go, it can hold about 36 boards at a time.
I'd found a really good solution on Alibaba too but I didn't want to wait 2 months for it to arrive
Dehydrator bakes around 190, not trying to use it to reflow, I just want to heat off any moisture left over after the cleaning process.
